name: "Magnolia" Quiz: Beware of Falling Frogs! | Movies | 20 Questions

questions.text: One of my favorite musicians of all time, Aimee Mann, wrote and performed most of the songs heard throughout this film.  Claudia Wilson Gator (Melora Walters) meets LAPD Officer Jim Kurring (John C. Reilly) only because she is playing an Aimee Mann song at a remarkably high volume level.  Which song is she playing that causes her neighbors to call the police and complain?
questions.explanation:
Momentum.

	All of these songs are heard throughout the course of the film, but when Kurring arrives at Claudia's apartment, it's "Momentum" that's blasting out of her speakers.

questions.text: One of the characters in this film reveals, via his or her own dialogue, that he or she is, in fact, a homosexual.  Which one?
questions.correct: Quiz Kid Donny Smith (William H. Macy)
questions.explanation:
Quiz Kid Donny Smith (William H. Macy)

	Donny, about halfway through the film, confesses his love for Brad, a male bartender.  As far as we know, none of the other characters mentioned in this question are homosexuals.

questions.text: There are approximately twelve major characters in this film.  How many of them are afflicted with cancer?
questions.explanation:
2 & two.

	Big Earl Partridge (Jason Robards) has both brain and lung cancer.  Jimmy Gator (Phillip Baker Hall) has bone cancer.  That's two.  (Frank T.J. Mackey's mother died of cancer over ten years prior to the events of this film, but since we never see her in the film, she's certainly not a "major character.")

questions.text: Frank T.J. Mackey (Tom Cruise), the mastermind of "Seduce and Destroy," uses an alias -- he is actually the son of television producer Earl Partridge (Jason Robards).  What is "Frank's" real first name?
questions.explanation:
Jack.

	Earl tells his nurse, Phil Parma, that his son's name is Jack, and that Jack is better known as infomercial celebrity Frank T.J. Mackey.

questions.text: A two-digit number appears MANY times throughout the film, in both obvious and subtle places.  This number is a reference to a particular passage from the Book of Exodus in the Holy Bible.  What is this two-digit number?
questions.explanation:
82 & 8:2 & 8-2 & 8 2.

	I'm no Bible expert, but my understanding is that Exodus 8:2 refers to the plague of frogs that was unleashed upon Egypt.  Fitting, given the bizarre climax of this film.

questions.text: Where or when do we NOT see or hear the two-digit number referring to the Exodus passage?
questions.correct: In the conversation that Linda Partridge has with her lawyer
options: In the prologue, when young Sydney Barringer attempts to commit suicide
In the audience of the game show hosted by Jimmy Gator
In the voice mail message Jim Kurring has recorded for his dating service
questions.explanation:
In the conversation that Linda Partridge has with her lawyer.

	Jim Kurring's voice mail message encourages women to leave him a message at box number 82.  An audience member in the stands during the taping of "What Do Kids Know?" is, inexplicably, holding up a cardboard sign reading "Exodus 8:2."  And, in the prologue, when Sydney Barringer is standing on the ledge, some coiled cabling off to his left is looped into the shape of the number 82.  (Check if you don't believe me!)  At no time does Linda or her lawyer (played by Michael Murphy) mention the number 82.

questions.text: Writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson appears in the film as the floor director of the game show "What Do Kids Know?".
questions.explanation:
False.

	Nope.  Kind of looks like PTA, but that floor director -- the guy in the baseball cap who "counts down" the seconds to air time with broad hand gestures -- is actually played by Clark Gregg, who also appeared in the film "State and Main".

questions.text: Magician Ricky Jay provides the voice-over narration for the film's prologue, but he also plays an on-screen role later in the film.  Which of these characters is played by Ricky Jay?
questions.correct: the producer of "What Do Kids Know?"
options: the nurse who tries to relieve Phil Parma at Earl Partridge's house, but is sent home
the pharmacist who fills prescriptions for Linda Partridge
questions.explanation:
the producer of "What Do Kids Know?".

	Ricky Jay plays Burt Ramsey, the bearded producer of the game show.  Ramsey is the man who sharply orders, "Go to the card!  Go to the CARD!" when Jimmy Gator collapses during a taping of the show.

questions.text: Earl Partridge owns an unusually large number of pets, all a specific type of animal.  Multiple representatives of what species of animal can be seen in the Partridge home?
questions.explanation:
dogs.

	There are at least four dogs in the Partridge home.

questions.text: Once Phil Parma learns that Frank T.J. Mackey, the infomercial sex guru, is actually Earl Partridge's son, he gets the idea to look for Mackey's ads in adult magazines, and orders said material from the local grocery store.  Which magazine DOES he order over the phone in order to aid his investigation?
questions.explanation:
Hustler.

	Phil seems surprised to learn that the local grocery delivery service supplies "Hustler" magazine upon request.  (He also orders up an issue of "Playboy.")

questions.text: Which character was struck by lightning, prior to the events shown in the film?
questions.explanation:
Quiz Kid Donny Smith.

	Both Avi Solomon (Al Molina) -- Donny's boss -- and a guy at the bar where Donny drowns his sorrows point out that Donny has been struck by lightning...more than once!  Ouch.

questions.text: The guests of Frank T.J. Mackey's "Seduce and Destroy" seminar are provided lunch along with a day's worth of instruction on procuring women.  According to Mackey's dialogue, what food item was at least part of the lunch provided?
questions.explanation:
nachos.

	When Mackey returns to the stage after the lunch break, he rhetorically asks the audience, "How were those nachos?"

questions.text: During one controversial sequence in the film, all of the major characters sing along with an Aimee Mann song that is part of the soundtrack.  Which song?
questions.explanation:
Wise Up.

	Even Earl Partridge, on the verge of death -- and Linda Partridge, half into her overdose -- sing along!

questions.text: Earl Partridge is given a dose of liquid morphine at one point in the film.  Who administers this lethal dose?
questions.explanation:
Phil Parma.

	Linda had planned to give her husband the lethal dose of morphine, but found herself unable to do so.  It was Phil who squeezed the dropper into Earl's mouth, well before "Frank" even arrived at Earl's house.

questions.text: Which character is clearly shown as being addicted to cocaine?
questions.explanation:
Claudia Wilson Gator.

	Claudia is shown using cocaine multiple times throughout the film.  None of the other characters listed are shown using cocaine at all.

questions.text: Late in the film, a plague of frogs rains down upon Los Angeles, causing extreme havoc and panic for most of the characters in the film.  Which character's life was actually SAVED by the plague of frogs?
questions.explanation:
Jimmy Gator.

	Jimmy was about to shoot himself in the head, but a frog crashed through his skylight and struck his hand, spoiling the shot.  None of the other characters mentioned were in life-threatening situations when the frogs began to fall.

questions.text: How many people in the film speak the thematically significant line, "The book says we may be through with the past, but the past ain't through with us," or a close paraphrase of same?
questions.explanation:
3 & three.

	The narrator says this during the prologue; Jimmy says it just before going onstage for his game show; and Donny Smith says it in the bar.  That's three.

questions.text: In the prologue, we're told a story of three murderers.  Which was NOT the name of one of those murderers?
questions.explanation:
Jones.

	The "irony" or "coincidence" of this story is that three men named Green, Berry, and Hill murdered a man in a London province called Greenberry Hill.

questions.text: In the last shot of the film, one character looks directly into the camera and smiles.  Which one?
questions.explanation:
Claudia Wilson Gator.

	As Aimee Mann's "Save Me" plays in the background and Jim Kurring is telling Claudia how much he wants to be a part of her life, Claudia looks right into the camera and smiles broadly -- a sign of hope for the future, one could say.  That's the final shot.

questions.text: "Magnolia" was Jason Robards' final theatrical film.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Sadly, this was the last film that Robards ever made for the big screen.  He died in 2000 of metastasized lung cancer at the age of 78.
